content.title: Tension-Type Headache
content.summary: Most common primary headache disorder characterized by bilateral, non-pulsating, mild-to-moderate head pain described as pressure or tightening, without significant nausea, photophobia, or aggravation by activity
key_points: Mild to moderate intensity; not aggravated by routine physical activity
Photophobia OR phonophobia (not both) may be present
Episodic (<15 days/month) vs chronic (≥15 days/month for >3 months)
Treatment: NSAIDs, acetaminophen; amitriptyline for chronic form

statement.text: Tension-type headache (TTH) is the most common primary headache disorder, characterized by bilateral, pressing or tightening (non-pulsating) pain of mild-to-moderate intensity that is not aggravated by routine physical activity and is not associated with nausea. Unlike migraine, patients can typically continue daily activities. TTH is classified as episodic (infrequent or frequent) or chronic based on frequency. First-line treatment for episodic TTH includes simple analgesics (NSAIDs, acetaminophen), while chronic TTH may benefit from preventive therapy with amitriptyline.
statement.formal: TTH = Bilateral + Pressing/tightening + Mild-moderate + NOT aggravated by activity + NO nausea + NOT both photophobia AND phonophobia

explanation.intuition: Tension-type headache is the 'everyday' headache most people have experienced - a dull, diffuse pressure as if a band is wrapped around the head. Unlike migraine, it doesn't throb, doesn't cause nausea, and doesn't force you to stop what you're doing. The name 'tension' historically suggested muscle tension as the cause, but the pathophysiology is now understood to be more complex, involving both peripheral and central sensitization mechanisms.
explanation.key_insight: The key diagnostic feature is what TTH LACKS: no throbbing, no nausea, no significant disability from the pain, no worsening with activity. This 'featureless' headache is diagnosed when migraine features are absent. Chronic TTH (≥15 days/month) can be quite debilitating despite mild individual attacks due to the cumulative burden.
explanation.technical_details: Peripheral mechanisms include myofascial pain (increased pericranial muscle tenderness) and nociceptor sensitization. Central mechanisms include sensitization of second-order neurons in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis and dysfunction of supraspinal pain modulation. Chronic TTH may represent a continuum with chronic migraine, sharing central sensitization features.

definitions_glossary.tension_type_headache: Primary headache with bilateral, pressing pain of mild-moderate intensity without migraine features
definitions_glossary.primary_headache: Headache without underlying structural or systemic cause (vs secondary headache)
definitions_glossary.episodic_tension_headache: TTH occurring <15 days per month; further divided into infrequent (<1/month) and frequent (1-14/month)
definitions_glossary.chronic_tension_headache: TTH occurring ≥15 days per month for >3 months
definitions_glossary.pressing_quality: Non-pulsating pain described as tightening, band-like, or squeezing sensation
definitions_glossary.photophobia: Sensitivity to light; may be present in TTH but NOT combined with phonophobia
definitions_glossary.phonophobia: Sensitivity to sound; may be present in TTH but NOT combined with photophobia
definitions_glossary.pericranial_tenderness: Tenderness of scalp and neck muscles on palpation; common in TTH
definitions_glossary.central_sensitization: Increased excitability of central pain pathways, contributing to chronic headache
definitions_glossary.medication_overuse_headache: Headache worsening due to frequent analgesic use; complicates chronic TTH treatment
definitions_glossary.amitriptyline: Tricyclic antidepressant used as first-line prophylaxis for chronic TTH
definitions_glossary.nsaids: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; first-line acute treatment for TTH

pathophysiology.mechanism: TTH pathophysiology involves both peripheral and central mechanisms. Peripheral sensitization includes myofascial trigger points, increased pericranial muscle tenderness, and nociceptor sensitization in craniocervical muscles. Central sensitization involves increased excitability of neurons in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis and impaired descending pain modulation. The transition from episodic to chronic TTH reflects progressive central sensitization.
contributing_factors: Muscular tension and myofascial trigger points

peripheral_central_model.episodic_tth: Primarily peripheral mechanisms (muscle tension, nociceptor activation)
peripheral_central_model.chronic_tth: Primarily central mechanisms (central sensitization, impaired pain modulation)

ichd3_criteria.a: At least 10 episodes fulfilling criteria B-D
ichd3_criteria.c: At least two of: bilateral location; pressing/tightening (non-pulsating) quality; mild-to-moderate intensity; not aggravated by routine physical activity
ichd3_criteria.d: Both: no nausea or vomiting; photophobia OR phonophobia (not both)
ichd3_criteria.e: Not better accounted for by another ICHD-3 diagnosis

classification.frequent_episodic: 1-14 days/month on average for >3 months (≥12 and <180 days/year)
classification.chronic: ≥15 days/month on average for >3 months (≥180 days/year)

diagnostic_criteria.with_pericranial_tenderness: Subclassification based on presence of increased pericranial muscle tenderness on manual palpation

acute_treatment.effectiveness: NNT ~3 for pain freedom at 2 hours
acute_treatment.caution: Limit to <10-15 days/month to avoid medication overuse headache

preventive_treatment.indication: Chronic TTH (≥15 days/month) or frequent episodic with significant disability
preventive_treatment.alternatives: Mirtazapine, venlafaxine (SNRIs may be less effective than TCAs)
preventive_treatment.duration: Trial for at least 2-3 months; gradual dose titration

non_pharmacological.physical_therapy: Posture correction, trigger point therapy, stretching
non_pharmacological.acupuncture: May have modest benefit in chronic TTH

medication_overuse_management.identification: Using simple analgesics ≥15 days/month or combination analgesics ≥10 days/month
medication_overuse_management.treatment: Withdrawal of overused medication; bridge with preventive

definition.@value: Most common primary headache characterized by bilateral, pressing, mild-to-moderate pain without migraine features like nausea or aggravation by activity

skos.scopeNote: Covers episodic and chronic tension-type headache per ICHD-3 criteria; distinguishes from migraine
skos.example: A 35-year-old office worker with bilateral 'squeezing' headaches occurring 3-4 times weekly for months, relieved by ibuprofen, able to continue working through the pain, no nausea or sensitivity to light

learning_objectives: Apply ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria for tension-type headache
Differentiate tension-type headache from migraine based on clinical features
Classify TTH as episodic (infrequent/frequent) or chronic based on frequency
Select appropriate acute and preventive treatments
Identify and manage medication overuse headache complicating TTH
clinical_pearls: TTH is the 'featureless' headache - defined by what it LACKS vs migraine
Can have photophobia OR phonophobia but NOT BOTH (both = migraine feature)
Chronic TTH (≥15 days/month) needs amitriptyline prophylaxis
Watch for medication overuse - limit acute analgesics to <10-15 days/month
Many 'tension headaches' are actually mild migraines - look for migraine features
Pericranial muscle tenderness on palpation supports diagnosis

board_yield.usmle_step2: Moderate - TTH vs migraine distinction, treatment
board_yield.usmle_step3: Moderate - chronic headache management, medication overuse

common_misconceptions: TTH is caused by stress and muscle tension (false - pathophysiology is multifactorial, includes central sensitization)
TTH cannot be disabling (false - chronic TTH causes significant cumulative disability)
Any bilateral headache is TTH (false - migraine can be bilateral; need to assess other features)
Muscle relaxants are effective for TTH (false - not proven effective; simple analgesics preferred)

skos:related.skos:note: Key differential diagnosis; migraine has throbbing, nausea, disability
Common complication of chronic TTH treatment

sources.source: Headache Classification Committee of the International Headache Society. The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition. Cephalalgia 2018;38:1-211
Bendtsen L, et al. EFNS guideline on the treatment of tension-type headache. Eur J Neurol. 2010;17:1318-25
Bradley's Neurology in Clinical Practice, 8th ed. Elsevier 2022

prov:wasDerivedFrom.dc:title: International Classification of Headache Disorders 3rd Edition
